work.p: Lines in this manuscript are similar to language in the prose preface to the 1855 Leaves of Grass: "that there is not a minute of the light or dark nor an acre of the earth or sea without it" (1855, p. vi).

This manuscript includes drafts of lines that appeared in the first poem in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, titled "Leaves of Grass," eventually titled "Song of Myself": "And mossy scabs of the wormfence, and heaped stones, and elder and mullen and pokeweed" (1855, p. 16). "And the mockingbird in the swamp never studied the gamut, yet trills pretty well to me, / And the look of the bay mare shames silliness out of me" (1855, p. 20). "And the cow crunching with depressed head surpassed any statue" (1855, p. 34). "Delicate sniffs of the seabreeze .... smells of sedgy grass and fields by the shore ... death-messages given in charge to survivors" (1855, p. 42).

A line in this manuscript is similar to a line that appeared in the poem that would later be titled "To Think of Time": "The earth is not an echo . . . . man and his life and all the things of his life are well-considered" (1855, p. 67).

Lines in this manuscript bear some resemblance to language in the poem eventually titled "A Song for Occupations": "The wonder every one sees in every one else he sees . . . . and the wonders that fill each minute of time forever and each acre of surface and space forever" (1855, p. 59).

Lines in this manuscript bear some resemblance to language in the manuscript poem Pictures: "And every hour of the day and night has given deposited with me copious pictures, / And every rod of land or sea affords me, as long as I live, inimitable pictures." The first lines of the notebook poem were revised and published as "My Picture-Gallery" in The American in October 1880. The poem was later published in Leaves of Grass as part of the "Autumn Rivulets" cluster (1881, p. 310).

titleStmt.title: And to me each minute
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Whitman probably drafted this manuscript in the early 1850s as he was preparing materials for the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. The manuscript includes lines that relate to the prose preface and to several of the poems in that edition, including the poems eventually titled "Song of Myself," "To Think of Time," and "A Song for Occupations." The manuscript also includes lines that relate to the manuscript poem "Pictures," which probably dates to the mid- to late 1850s.

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: [And to me each minute]
bibl.orgName: The Walt Whitman Collection, Harry Ransom Humanities Research Center, The University of Texas at Austin
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
Notes about the arrangement and production of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass are written on the back of this manuscript.

revisionDesc.change: checked and corrected, added corresps and relations

lg.l:
And to me each minute of the night and day is chock with something as vital and visible
vital live as flesh is
And I say the stars are not echoes
And I perceive that the salt marsh sea sedgy weed has delicious refreshing odors;
And potatoes and milk afford a fat breakfast dinner of state,;

And I dare not say the guess the chipping bird bay mare mocking bird is less than I sings as well as I,
because although she reads no newspaper; never learned the gamut;

And to shake my friendly right hand governors
and millionaires shall stand all day,
waiting their turns.—

And on to me each acre of the earth land and sea, I behold exhibits to me
perpetual unending marvellous pictures;

They fill the worm‑fence, and lie on the heaped stones,
and are hooked to the elder and poke‑weed;
And to me each every minute of the night and day is filled with a live joy

And to me the cow crunching with depressed head surpasses is an a
every statue perfect and plumb;
